title: U.K. Seeing More Realistic Pricing, Buyers Willing to Sign Deals
text:
U.K. home sellers have gotten realistic about how much buyers are willing to pay as political uncertainty surrounding Brexit weighs on people’s minds, according to new research from listing site Zoopla.



The median home in the U.K. sold for a little more than 96% of its asking price over the last 12 months, a sign that homeowners are pricing homes to sell, according to data released on Tuesday from the government Land Registry and Zoopla. Countrywide, buyers were only able to negotiate an average discount of £8,000 (US$9,665 ).

In a few towns, most homes are selling at or over the initial listing price, including more affordable areas like Driffield, Yorkshire; Dronfield in the East Midlands; and Salford, part of Greater Manchester, according to the report.



“This close relationship between initial listing and final sale prices points to a healthy and robust property market, in which estate agents and sellers alike are well-versed in and realistic about property values,” said Laura Howard, a spokeswoman for Zoopla, in the report.



The relatively small average discount for U.K. homes follows a drop in overall sales in the country, as buyers and sellers who are able to wait out the political uncertainty hold off on transacting.



By contrast, more expensive parts of the country, particularly anywhere in and around London, continue to see more price negotiability, the data shows.

The affluent down of Ascot, in East Berkshire, has seen some of the biggest discounts for a prime area outside of London. The average home there traded for £550,000 over the past 12 months, an average discount of nearly 8% (or £50,000).



The trend is the same in London, where more affordable neighborhoods have logged slim discounts compared to luxury strongholds like Camden and Kensington, Zoopla found.



Buyers in Camden got an average 9% discount totaling roughly £75,000, while those in Kensington knocked 8.3% off the listing price for a total discount of £116,000.
